unnormalised: The first time I encountered a real coding challenge was back in my final year at IIT Delhi. We were tasked with developing a full-stack application for a local NGO. It was a web-based system to manage their donation records, volunteers, and beneficiaries – a project that sounded straightforward on paper but quickly became a whirlwind of "WTF" moments.
normalised: The first time I encountered a real coding challenge was back in my final year at I-I-T Delhi. We were tasked with developing a full-stack application for a local N-G-O. It was a web-based system to manage their donation records, volunteers, and beneficiaries – a project that sounded straightforward on paper but quickly became a whirlwind of "W-T-F" moments.

unnormalised: Our team, consisting of me, Priya, Rakesh, and Aisha, decided to use Python with Django for the backend and React for the frontend. Priya, our self-proclaimed "CSS guru," volunteered to handle the user interface, while Rakesh, always the meticulous one, took charge of the database design using PostgreSQL. Aisha, with her knack for problem-solving, tackled the authentication and security aspects, and I, well, I was supposed to tie everything together. We started by forking a basic django template on GitHub.
normalised: Our team, consisting of me, Priya, Rakesh, and Aisha, decided to use Python with Django for the backend and React for the frontend. Priya, our self-proclaimed "C-S-S guru," volunteered to handle the user interface, while Rakesh, always the meticulous one, took charge of the database design using P-o-s-t-g-r-e-S-Q-L. Aisha, with her knack for problem-solving, tackled the authentication and security aspects, and I, well, I was supposed to tie everything together. We started by forking a basic django template on G-i-t-H-u-b.

unnormalised: The initial setup went smoothly enough. We had our development environment configured, the database schema drafted, and a rudimentary user interface taking shape. Then came the first hurdle: integrating UPI payments. The NGO wanted to receive donations directly through the app, and integrating a payment gateway proved to be more complex than we had anticipated. We spent countless hours poring over documentation, grappling with API keys, and debugging error messages that seemed to appear out of nowhere. Rakesh spent almost 24 hrs straight debugging payment integration.
normalised: The initial setup went smoothly enough. We had our development environment configured, the database schema drafted, and a rudimentary user interface taking shape. Then came the first hurdle: integrating U-P-I payments. The N-G-O wanted to receive donations directly through the app, and integrating a payment gateway proved to be more complex than we had anticipated. We spent countless hours poring over documentation, grappling with A-P-I keys, and debugging error messages that seemed to appear out of nowhere. Rakesh spent almost twenty four hours straight debugging payment integration.

unnormalised: One particularly frustrating evening, after battling a CORS error for what felt like an eternity, I decided to take a break and grab a chai from the nearby dhaba. As I sat there sipping the sweet, milky tea, I overheard a conversation between two auto-rickshaw drivers discussing a similar problem with their payment app. Turns out, one of them had encountered the same CORS issue and had found a workaround by configuring the server to accept requests from all origins (not exactly best practice, but hey, we were desperate!).
normalised: One particularly frustrating evening, after battling a C-O-R-S error for what felt like an eternity, I decided to take a break and grab a chai from the nearby dhaba. As I sat there sipping the sweet, milky tea, I overheard a conversation between two auto-rickshaw drivers discussing a similar problem with their payment app. Turns out, one of them had encountered the same C-O-R-S issue and had found a workaround by configuring the server to accept requests from all origins (not exactly best practice, but hey, we were desperate!).

unnormalised: Armed with this newfound knowledge, I rushed back to our lab and implemented the workaround (after adding proper security layers, of course!). To our relief, it worked! We were able to successfully process a test payment of Rs. 10. It was a small victory, but it felt like a major breakthrough.

We were able to successfully process a test payment of rupee ten. It was a small victory, but it felt like a major breakthrough.

unnormalised: The rest of the project presented its own set of challenges, from optimizing database queries to handling file uploads, but we tackled them one by one, drawing on our collective knowledge and experiences. We even managed to integrate a reporting feature that generated monthly donation summaries in PDF format. The app had to handle about 5000 records a day.
normalised: The rest of the project presented its own set of challenges, from optimizing database queries to handling file uploads, but we tackled them one by one, drawing on our collective knowledge and experiences. We even managed to integrate a reporting feature that generated monthly donation summaries in P-D-F format. The app had to handle about five thousand records a day.

unnormalised: Finally, after weeks of sleepless nights, countless cups of chai, and endless lines of code, we deployed the application to a server hosted on AWS. The NGO staff were thrilled with the result, and the app proved to be a valuable tool for managing their operations. We even got a shout-out in the local newspaper, which was a nice bonus. More importantly, the experience taught me the importance of teamwork, perseverance, and the occasional chai break when facing a coding challenge.
